Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down harder than I’d ever seen, thick flakes swirling in the headlights as I gripped the steering wheel. My passenger kept glancing at his watch, his voice tight as he reminded me—again—how important it was to reach the airport on time. I nodded, heart pounding, trying to focus on the slippery road. My phone buzzed in the cupholder. I knew it was my mom; we always texted at this hour, and she’d worry if I didn’t reply. She expected a quick update, maybe a photo of the snow, a reassurance that I was safe. But my passenger’s anxious sighs pressed on me, and I knew even a glance at my phone could risk our safety. I felt torn, the weight of my mother’s worry and my duty to this stranger both heavy on my chest. The storm outside was nothing compared to the storm inside me, as I wrestled with who needed me more in this moment.
